content.text: Measure and record the diameter \(d\) of the short sample of wire that is attached to the card. You may remove the wire from the card

Measure and record the width \(w\) of one of the metre rules, as shown in Fig. 2.1
Select the two longer pieces of string
Tie the ends of one piece of string to make a loop
Measure and record the length \(l\) of this loop, as shown in Fig. 2.2
Repeat (ii) with the other long piece of string. The length of this loop should be the same as that in (iii)
Use the stands to set up the two metre rules and the two loops of string as shown in Fig. 2.3
The rules should be horizontal with the scale markings facing you
The loops should be vertical, parallel to each other and placed at the \(5\mathrm{cm}\) and \(95\mathrm{cm}\) marks on both rules
Using your values in (a) and (b)(iii), determine the distance \(d\) using the relationship
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(d\)
percentage uncertainty =   .........
Move the left end of the bottom rule towards you and the right end away from you
Release the rule and watch the movement
The left end of the rule will move away from you and back towards you, completing a swing
The time taken for one complete swing is \(T\)
By timing several of these complete swings, determine an accurate value for \(T\)
Repeat (b), (c)(i), (c)(ii) and (d) for the shorter lengths of string

In this experiment you will investigate how the motion of a metre rule depends on the length of the string loops used to suspend it
